meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! Welcome to my review of Half-Minute Hero, the game that'll make you laugh, cry, and maybe even question the meaning of life (but only if you're a critic like me).

Let's get this party started with some fun facts: did you know that Half-Minute Hero has been praised by critics? Like, really praised. I mean, Play Magazine gave it 95/100, Worth Playing gave it 90/100... even Game Informer chimed in with an 80/100. Yeah, they all love this game! (Except maybe not Game Revolution, but we'll get to that later).

So, what's the big deal about Half-Minute Hero? For starters, it's got a wacky concept: you play as a hero who can only save the world in... wait for it... 30 seconds at a time. That's right, folks! The game is all about quickie quests and bite-sized battles. It's like a PSP-sized bag of potato chips – addictive, but ultimately leaving you feeling a little guilty.

Now, I know what you're thinking: "How do I get my fix of Half-Minute Hero goodness?" Well, here's the best part: you can play it in short sessions, or you can binge-play for hours on end. It's like having your own personal gaming snack attack!

But don't just take my word for it – what about those fancy-pants critics? What do they say?

Play Magazine says it's "utterly excellent in execution" (whatever that means).
Worth Playing calls it "extremely difficult to put down" (I couldn't agree more, guys!).
Game Informer claims it's got a "sense of humor and the developer's obvious appreciation of the games it parodies" (okay, okay, I'll stop using quotes now).

And then there's Game Revolution... oh boy. They gave it 67/100, saying it's "not long, not deep, but sometimes that's just what you need: a fun – albeit short – hit to keep you going." Yeah, well, thanks for the backhanded compliment, guys!

All joking aside (just kidding, I'm just getting started!), Half-Minute Hero is an absolute blast. It's the perfect game for commuters, students on breaks, or anyone looking for a fun distraction.

So, go ahead and give it a try! And if you don't like it... well, you can always play it in half-minute increments, right?
